title: Jeremiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 17.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:5, what does the LORD say about the man who trusts in man?
questions.correctAnswer: He is cursed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:5 states, 'Cursed be the man that trusteth in man, and maketh flesh his arm, and whose heart departeth from the LORD.'

questions.question: What image is used in Jeremiah 17:8 to describe the man who trusts in the LORD?
options: A tree planted by the waters
A bird flying in the sky
questions.correctAnswer: A tree planted by the waters
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:8 says, 'For he shall be as a tree planted by the waters, and that spreadeth out her roots by the river.'

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 17:9 says the heart is deceitful above all things and desperately wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:9 clearly states, 'The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked.'

questions.question: What will happen to the man who gets riches not by right according to Jeremiah 17:11?
options: He will live long and prosper
He shall leave them and be a fool at the end
He will be honored by the people
He will be blessed by God
questions.correctAnswer: He shall leave them and be a fool at the end
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:11 says, 'he that getteth riches, and not by right, shall leave them in the midst of his days, and at his end shall be a fool.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 17:14: 'Heal me, O LORD, and I shall be _____; save me, and I shall be saved.'
questions.correctAnswer: healed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:14 says, 'Heal me, O LORD, and I shall be healed; save me, and I shall be saved.'

questions.question: Who does the LORD command Jeremiah to address in Jeremiah 17:20?
options: The kings of Judah, all Judah, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem
The children of Israel in exile
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of Judah, all Judah, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:20 says, 'Hear ye the word of the LORD, ye kings of Judah, and all Judah, and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem.'

questions.question: What specific instruction is given in Jeremiah 17:21 about the sabbath day?
options: Do not carry burdens through the gates of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Do not carry burdens through the gates of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:21 instructs, 'Take heed to yourselves, and bear no burden on the sabbath day, nor bring it in by the gates of Jerusalem.'

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 17:23 says the people listened carefully and obeyed the LORD's commands.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:23 says, 'But they obeyed not, neither inclined their ear, but made their neck stiff, that they might not hear.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:13, what happens to those who forsake the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be ashamed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:13 states, 'all that forsake thee shall be ashamed.'

questions.question: What does God say He will do if people do not hallow the sabbath day as commanded, according to Jeremiah 17:27?
options: Kindle a fire in the gates of Jerusalem that will not be quenched
questions.correctAnswer: Kindle a fire in the gates of Jerusalem that will not be quenched
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:27 says, 'then will I kindle a fire in the gates thereof, and it shall devour the palaces of Jerusalem, and it shall not be quenched.'

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 17:7 says that blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD and whose hope is the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:7 states, 'Blessed is the man that trusteth in the LORD, and whose hope the LORD is.'

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say about his own ministry in Jeremiah 17:16?
options: He has not hastened to follow God
He has desired the woeful day
questions.correctAnswer: He has not hastened to follow God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:16 says, 'I have not hastened from being a pastor to follow thee: neither have I desired the woeful day.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:10, what does the LORD do?
options: Search the heart and give every man according to his ways
questions.correctAnswer: Search the heart and give every man according to his ways
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:10 states, 'I the LORD search the heart, I try the reins, even to give every man according to his ways.'

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:12, what is described as a glorious high throne from the beginning?
questions.correctAnswer: The place of our sanctuary
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:12 says, 'A glorious high throne from the beginning is the place of our sanctuary.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 17:9: 'The heart is ______ above all things, and desperately wicked.'
questions.correctAnswer: deceitful
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:9 states, 'The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked.'

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 17 teach us about trust and dependence in daily life?
options: Trust in man and rely on human strength
Trust in the LORD and place hope in Him
Ignore both God and man and trust only yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD and place hope in Him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:5-8 contrasts trusting in man versus trusting in the LORD, highlighting that trusting God leads to blessing and stability, whereas trusting man leads to curse and barrenness.

questions.question: A believer is feeling spiritually dry and discouraged. Based on Jeremiah 17, what encouragement would you share about spiritual resilience?
options: Like a tree planted by waters, those who trust God will remain fruitful even in drought
Spiritual dryness means God has forsaken you
Only those who are perfect will remain fruitful
Spiritual fruitfulness depends solely on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: Like a tree planted by waters, those who trust God will remain fruitful even in drought
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:7-8 uses the metaphor of a tree planted by water that remains green and fruitful despite heat and drought, symbolizing the stability and blessing of trusting God.

questions.question: What warning does Jeremiah 17 give regarding the deceitfulness of the human heart?
options: The heart is trustworthy and always leads us right
The heart is deceitful above all things and desperately wicked
The heart is irrelevant to moral choices
questions.correctAnswer: The heart is deceitful above all things and desperately wicked
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:9 emphasizes the deep deceitfulness of the human heart, warning believers to rely on God’s searching and guidance rather than their own understanding.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 17 illustrate God's justice in dealing with people's actions?
options: God judges according to outward appearance
God searches the heart and gives according to one's ways and deeds
questions.correctAnswer: God searches the heart and gives according to one's ways and deeds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:10 shows God's intimate knowledge of the heart and that He rewards or punishes according to the fruit of each person's actions.

questions.question: A person is tempted to gain wealth unjustly. According to Jeremiah 17, what is the likely outcome of such behavior?
options: They will be respected and honored
They will leave their riches at midlife and be considered foolish
They will live a long and blessed life
They will be immediately rewarded by God
questions.correctAnswer: They will leave their riches at midlife and be considered foolish
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:11 compares unjust gain to a partridge that sits on eggs it did not hatch, warning that unjustly acquired riches will be lost prematurely and bring shame.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 17 say about Sabbath observance and work ethic for God’s people?
options: Carry burdens and do work on the Sabbath freely
Bear no burden and do no work on the Sabbath, but hallow the day
Ignore the Sabbath and focus on personal convenience
Only priests should observe the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Bear no burden and do no work on the Sabbath, but hallow the day
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:21-22 commands the people to refrain from carrying burdens and working on the Sabbath and to honor the day as God commanded their ancestors.

questions.question: What consequence does Jeremiah 17 warn will come if the people do not honor the Sabbath?
options: A fire will be kindled in the gates of Jerusalem and will not be quenched
questions.correctAnswer: A fire will be kindled in the gates of Jerusalem and will not be quenched
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:27 warns that disobedience to Sabbath rest will cause God to kindle a fire that will consume the palaces of Jerusalem, symbolizing judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 17 emphasize prayer and personal devotion in times of trouble?
options: Pray for healing and salvation, acknowledging God as your praise
Avoid prayer and rely on others
Ignore God and focus on worldly solutions
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for healing and salvation, acknowledging God as your praise
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:14 expresses a personal plea for healing and salvation, recognizing God as the source of praise and help in trials.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 17, those who forsake the LORD will be ashamed and be written in the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:13 states that those who forsake the LORD will be ashamed and their names written in the earth because they have abandoned the fountain of living waters.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 17 encourages God’s people to obey His commands with a willing heart rather than stiff necked rebellion.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:23 describes how the people made their necks stiff and refused to listen or receive instruction, implying that obedience requires a willing heart.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 17 compares a person who trusts in the LORD to a ________ planted by the waters, spreading roots by the river.
questions.correctAnswer: tree
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:8 uses the metaphor of a tree planted by the waters to illustrate the stability and fruitfulness of one who trusts in God.

questions.question: What biblical principle about parenting and family faith is shown in Jeremiah 17 regarding remembering altars and groves?
options: Children remember altars and groves by green trees on high hills
Spiritual heritage is irrelevant to children
Only parents are responsible for faith
questions.correctAnswer: Children remember altars and groves by green trees on high hills
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:2 indicates that children remember their spiritual heritage through altars and groves, stressing the importance of teaching faith within the family.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 17, how should believers respond when persecuted or opposed for their faith?
options: Pray that persecutors be confounded but not the believer
questions.correctAnswer: Pray that persecutors be confounded but not the believer
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:18 shows the prayer that those who persecute the prophet be confounded while he himself is preserved, demonstrating reliance on God’s justice rather than personal revenge.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 17 instruct believers to share the Gospel and be witnesses in community life?
options: Stand in city gates and proclaim God's word
questions.correctAnswer: Stand in city gates and proclaim God's word
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:19-20 commands the prophet to stand in the gates where kings and people enter and declare the word of the LORD, modeling public proclamation of God's message.

questions.question: What future blessing is promised if the people obey God’s command to keep the Sabbath holy?
options: Kings and princes will enter the city riding on thrones and horses, and the city will remain forever
The city will be destroyed immediately
They will become poor and scattered
questions.correctAnswer: Kings and princes will enter the city riding on thrones and horses, and the city will remain forever
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:24-25 promises that if the people keep the Sabbath holy and refrain from work, kings and princes will enter Jerusalem and the city will endure forever.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 17.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 17:5, what is the LORD's pronouncement concerning the man who trusts in man and whose heart departs from the LORD?
options: He is blessed and will prosper
questions.correctAnswer: He is cursed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:5 explicitly states, 'Cursed be the man that trusteth in man... and whose heart departeth from the LORD.'

questions.question: Which metaphor in Jeremiah 17:6 describes the fate of one who trusts in man rather than the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Heath in the desert
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:6 compares such a person to 'the heath in the desert,' symbolizing barrenness and desolation.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:8, what characteristic is attributed to the man who trusts in the LORD?
options: He shall be like a partridge without eggs
He shall be as a tree planted by the waters
He shall be a wanderer in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be as a tree planted by the waters
questions.explanation: The verse uses the imagery of a tree planted by water to symbolize stability and continual fruitfulness for the man who trusts in the LORD.

questions.question: What is described as 'deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked' in Jeremiah 17:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The heart
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:9 states that 'The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked,' emphasizing human internal corruption.

questions.question: Jeremiah 17:10 indicates that the LORD searches and tries the heart and reins in order to do what?
options: To give every man according to his ways and the fruit of his doings
To bless the righteous with wealth
questions.correctAnswer: To give every man according to his ways and the fruit of his doings
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's role in judging individuals based on their actions and intentions.

questions.question: The analogy in Jeremiah 17:11 compares a man who gains riches unjustly to what bird?
questions.correctAnswer: Partridge
questions.explanation: The verse compares such a man to a partridge sitting on eggs but not hatching them, symbolizing futility and foolishness.

questions.question: What is referred to as 'a glorious high throne from the beginning' in Jeremiah 17:12?
questions.correctAnswer: The place of our sanctuary
questions.explanation: The verse describes the sanctuary as a glorious high throne established from the beginning, highlighting its divine significance.

questions.question: Jeremiah 17:13 calls the LORD what metaphor, emphasizing His life-giving nature?
questions.correctAnswer: The fountain of living waters
questions.explanation: This metaphor in verse 13 underscores God as the source of spiritual life and sustenance.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 17:14, what two acts of the LORD does Jeremiah request as a plea for personal restoration?
questions.correctAnswer: Heal me and save me
questions.explanation: The verse is a personal prayer asking God for healing and salvation, affirming trust in His deliverance.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah's response to the demand for the word of the LORD as recorded in Jeremiah 17:15?
options: He hastened to deliver it immediately
He delayed in giving the prophecy
He declared he had not hastened from being a pastor
questions.correctAnswer: He declared he had not hastened from being a pastor
questions.explanation: Verse 16 clarifies Jeremiah's commitment to his prophetic calling, indicating he did not rush or desire calamity.

questions.question: Jeremiah 17:18 contains a plea for what specific outcome upon those who persecute him?
options: That they be confounded and destroyed with double destruction
That they be converted to faith
questions.correctAnswer: That they be confounded and destroyed with double destruction
questions.explanation: The verse expresses Jeremiah's desire for divine justice against his persecutors, asking for their confusion and severe punishment.

questions.question: What instruction does the LORD give Jeremiah in Jeremiah 17:19 regarding the gates of Jerusalem?
options: To stand in the gates and deliver the LORD's word
To decorate the gates with symbols
questions.correctAnswer: To stand in the gates and deliver the LORD's word
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:19 instructs him to stand in the city gates where kings and people enter and exit to proclaim God's message.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:21-22, what specific Sabbath observance does the LORD command the people of Judah?
options: To fast and pray all day
To bear no burden nor do any work
questions.correctAnswer: To bear no burden nor do any work
questions.explanation: The LORD commands cessation of all work and carrying burdens through the city gates on the Sabbath, emphasizing holiness of the day.

questions.question: What consequences does the LORD warn in Jeremiah 17:27 if the Sabbath laws are not observed?
options: A fire kindled in the gates that devours the palaces
questions.correctAnswer: A fire kindled in the gates that devours the palaces
questions.explanation: Verse 27 warns of a consuming fire in Jerusalem's gates as punishment for Sabbath desecration.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 17 emphasizes that the heart is righteous and trustworthy without divine intervention.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:9 states the heart is 'deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked,' highlighting the need for God's judgment.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:5-6, what is the condition and consequence of trusting in man rather than God?
options: He shall be like a tree planted by the waters
He shall be like the heath in the desert, inhabiting parched places
He shall be blessed and fruitful in drought
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be like the heath in the desert, inhabiting parched places
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:5-6 states that the man who trusts in man and departs from the LORD will be like the heath in the desert, unable to see good and living in desolation. This echoes Psalm 1:3 where the blessed man trusts in God and is like a tree by water, contrasting the wicked who wither like chaff (Psalm 1:4). Jesus teaches in John 15:5 the necessity of abiding in Him to bear fruit, and Proverbs 3:5 warns against trusting in one's own understanding.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 17:7-8, how is the man who trusts in the LORD described?
options: Like a partridge sitting on unhatched eggs
Like a tree planted by the waters with green leaves
Like a mountain given to spoil
Like a desert shrub without fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Like a tree planted by the waters with green leaves
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:7-8 describes the man trusting in the LORD as a tree planted by waters, whose leaves remain green and who yields fruit in drought. This symbolizes stability and divine blessing, consistent with Psalm 1:3 and Jesus’ metaphor in John 15:5 about abiding in Him to bear fruit. Isaiah 44:3 also speaks of God watering His people to sustain them.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 17:9 teach about the human heart?
options: The heart is pure and trustworthy
The heart is deceitful above all things and desperately wicked
The heart easily discerns God's will
The heart is always faithful to God
questions.correctAnswer: The heart is deceitful above all things and desperately wicked
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:9 declares the heart's deceitfulness and wickedness, emphasizing human sinfulness and need for divine grace. This is echoed in Genesis 6:5, Jeremiah 17:10 about God searching the heart, and Jesus’ teaching in Mark 7:21-23 on the evil that proceeds from the heart. Romans 3:10-18 also underscores humanity’s inherent sinfulness.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:10, what does the LORD do regarding the heart and actions of man?
options: He ignores the hidden thoughts of man
He tries the reins and gives to each according to their ways and deeds
He judges only the outward appearance
He rewards everyone equally regardless of deeds
questions.correctAnswer: He tries the reins and gives to each according to their ways and deeds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:10 affirms God's omniscience and justice, as He searches the heart and rewards or punishes according to deeds. This reflects biblical theology seen in 1 Samuel 16:7 where God judges the heart, Romans 2:6 about God rendering to each according to works, and Hebrews 4:12-13 concerning God's piercing knowledge of human hearts.

questions.question: What warning is given in Jeremiah 17:11 about those who gain riches unjustly?
options: They will leave their riches in the midst of days and be considered fools
They will be honored among men
questions.correctAnswer: They will leave their riches in the midst of days and be considered fools
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:11 compares unjustly gained riches to a partridge sitting on eggs it does not hatch, indicating futility and folly. This aligns with Proverbs 13:11 which condemns ill-gotten wealth, and Luke 12:15 where Jesus warns against greed. James 5:1-6 also addresses the judgment on those who hoard unjust wealth.

questions.question: What is described as a 'glorious high throne from the beginning' in Jeremiah 17:12?
options: The throne of the kings of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: The place of the sanctuary
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:12 identifies the glorious high throne as the place of God's sanctuary, signifying divine majesty and eternal kingship. This is consistent with Psalm 47:8 and Psalm 99:1 describing God's throne as glorious, and Hebrews 8:1 referencing Christ's heavenly sanctuary. It reflects God's sovereign rule through His sanctuary.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:13, what happens to those who forsake the LORD, the fountain of living waters?
options: They shall be written in the earth and be ashamed
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be written in the earth and be ashamed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:13 states that those who forsake God will be recorded in the earth and ashamed, highlighting consequences of spiritual apostasy. This corresponds to Psalm 9:17 about the wicked being remembered no more, John 4:14 where Jesus offers living water to believers, and Revelation 20:15 concerning the fate of those not written in the book of life.

questions.question: What prayer does Jeremiah offer in Jeremiah 17:14?
options: Heal me, O LORD, and I shall be healed; save me, and I shall be saved
Judge me, O LORD, according to my deeds
Let me not see the day of evil
questions.correctAnswer: Heal me, O LORD, and I shall be healed; save me, and I shall be saved
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:14 expresses a plea for healing and salvation from God, acknowledging Him as the source of restoration. This echoes Psalm 103:3 about God forgiving and healing, Isaiah 53:5 about the Messiah’s healing, and James 5:15 regarding prayer for the sick. It reveals trust in God’s redemptive power.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 17:15-16, how does Jeremiah describe his response to God's word despite opposition?
options: He hastened to avoid delivering God's word
He did not desire the woeful day and spoke rightly before God
He sought to please the people over God
questions.correctAnswer: He did not desire the woeful day and spoke rightly before God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:15-16 reveals Jeremiah’s integrity and reluctance about prophesying doom, yet he faithfully delivers God’s word. This aligns with Ezekiel 2:3-5 about reluctant prophets, 2 Timothy 4:2 about preaching the word in season and out, and Acts 20:24 regarding fulfilling ministry despite hardships.

questions.question: What instruction does the LORD give Jeremiah in Jeremiah 17:19-20 regarding the gates of Jerusalem?
options: To stand in the temple and offer sacrifices
To stand in the gates and proclaim the word to kings and inhabitants
To flee the city and warn the nations
To destroy the gates as a sign
questions.correctAnswer: To stand in the gates and proclaim the word to kings and inhabitants
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:19-20 commands Jeremiah to stand in the city gates, the entrances for kings and people, to proclaim God’s word. This role as a public prophet echoes Nehemiah 8:1-2 where the law is read publicly, and Acts 5:20 where the apostles are instructed to speak in the temple and streets. It underscores the call to faithful witness before rulers and people.

questions.question: What Sabbath observance was commanded in Jeremiah 17:21-22?
options: No burdens to be brought in or carried out through Jerusalem's gates on the Sabbath
No sacrifices to be offered on the Sabbath
Only priests may work on the Sabbath
All trades must cease except farming
questions.correctAnswer: No burdens to be brought in or carried out through Jerusalem's gates on the Sabbath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:21-22 commands cessation of burdens and work on the Sabbath to keep it holy, consistent with Exodus 20:8-11 and 31:15-17. Nehemiah 13:15-22 also recounts similar Sabbath regulations. Jesus taught the Sabbath was made for man (Mark 2:27), emphasizing its proper observance rather than legalism.

questions.question: What was the people's response to Jeremiah's message about the Sabbath in Jeremiah 17:23?
options: They inclined their ear and heeded the word
They made their neck stiff and did not hear or receive instruction
questions.correctAnswer: They made their neck stiff and did not hear or receive instruction
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:23 describes the people's stubbornness and refusal to obey, a common theme in prophetic literature (Isaiah 6:9-10, Ezekiel 2:4-5). This hardness of heart parallels Jesus’ lament in Matthew 13:15 about people’s inability to hear and understand the word.

questions.question: What blessing does the LORD promise if the people obey His Sabbath commands according to Jeremiah 17:24-25?
options: The city shall be destroyed by fire
Kings and princes will enter Jerusalem riding on chariots and horses
They will be taken captive by enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Kings and princes will enter Jerusalem riding on chariots and horses
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:24-25 promises the presence of kings and princes riding in Jerusalem if the Sabbath is kept holy, symbolizing peace and divine favor. This echoes 2 Chronicles 7:14 about blessings following obedience, and Isaiah 60:3 where nations come to the light of Zion. Luke 19:38-40 speaks of Christ entering Jerusalem with royal acclaim.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 17:26, what will the people bring to the house of the LORD if they obey the Sabbath?
options: Burnt offerings, sacrifices, meat offerings, incense, and sacrifices of praise
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt offerings, sacrifices, meat offerings, incense, and sacrifices of praise
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:26 lists various offerings that will be brought to God’s house, highlighting worship and covenant faithfulness. This reflects Leviticus 1-7 on sacrificial laws, Psalm 141:2 about incense as prayer, and Hebrews 13:15 encouraging continual praise to God. Worship includes both sacrifice and praise.

questions.question: What consequence does Jeremiah warn will come if the people do not keep the Sabbath holy according to Jeremiah 17:27?
options: The gates of Jerusalem will be fortified
A fire will be kindled in the gates which will devour the palaces and not be quenched
The people will prosper and multiply
The Sabbath will be forgotten without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: A fire will be kindled in the gates which will devour the palaces and not be quenched
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 17:27 warns that disobedience to Sabbath laws will result in a consuming fire in the gates of Jerusalem, symbolizing judgment and destruction. This is consistent with prophetic warnings of judgment in Isaiah 1:28, Ezekiel 22:20-22, and the final judgment imagery in Revelation 20:9-10.
